claim:
Overview of DSLP laboratories
DLSP current activities take place in three KEMRI laboratories, one in Kisumu and two in Nairobi (Fig. 1).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Physical location of Diagnostics and Laboratory Systems Program (DLSP) in Kenya and 10 county laboratory systems strengthening for the detection of Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR), 4 Acute Febrile Illness (AFI) surveillance sites and 5 National Influenza Surveillance sites

claim: In Kenya, DGHP has supported investigations into outbreaks of respiratory diseases (e.g., influenza, pertussis), diarrheal diseases (e.g., cholera, Salmonella Typhi, shigellosis), aflatoxicosis, and vector-borne diseases (e.g., Zika, dengue, chikungunya, Rift Valley fever viruses) (Fig. 3) [9, 22–27].
title: Fig. 3.
caption: Number of annual outbreak responses in Kenya and the region by disease syndrome supported by DLSP

claim: Arrows represent implementation of Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) and TaqMan Array Card (TAC)Fig. 3.
title: Fig. 3.
caption: Number of annual outbreak responses in Kenya and the region by disease syndrome supported by DLSP

claim:
The complete number of outbreaks and training performed in the region is summarized in Fig. 4.Development of new diagnostic technology to detect emerging and re-emerging pathogens
The diagnostic capacity in DLSP laboratories has been augmenting annually since 2004.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Countries that DGHP supported for training and/or outbreak response from 2006 to 2016

claim: To date DLSP, across its three participating laboratories, is capable of testing for 153 different pathogens by rRT-PCR, serological assays, microscopy, bacterial and viral culture, immunofluorescence and TAC. (Fig. 2).
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Number of parasites, viruses and bacterium in human, animal and environmental specimens the DLSP laboratory can test using diagnostic assays by year. Blue = parasites, orange = viruses, teal = bacterium. Arrows represent implementation of Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) and TaqMan Array Card (TAC)

claim: Within 3 years, the project will expand to include an additional 8 counties with improved capacity in microbiology techniques, AMR, specimen referral and shipping (Fig. 1).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Physical location of Diagnostics and Laboratory Systems Program (DLSP) in Kenya and 10 county laboratory systems strengthening for the detection of Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR), 4 Acute Febrile Illness (AFI) surveillance sites and 5 National Influenza Surveillance sites

claim: As of 2016, NPHLS NIC has successfully assumed diagnostic testing responsibility for 2 of the 5 influenza sentinel surveillance sites in the country (Fig. 1).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Physical location of Diagnostics and Laboratory Systems Program (DLSP) in Kenya and 10 county laboratory systems strengthening for the detection of Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR), 4 Acute Febrile Illness (AFI) surveillance sites and 5 National Influenza Surveillance sites

claim: Over the last decade DLSP trained technical staff from Kenya and neighboring countries in PCR, ELISA and microbiology diagnostic techniques to detect multiple pathogens (Fig. 2).
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Number of parasites, viruses and bacterium in human, animal and environmental specimens the DLSP laboratory can test using diagnostic assays by year. Blue = parasites, orange = viruses, teal = bacterium. Arrows represent implementation of Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) and TaqMan Array Card (TAC)

claim:
This capacity was recently recognized by the newly established African Centers of Disease Control which has designated Kenya as a regional collaborating center, to support disease prevention and outbreak response throughout the region.Acknowledgements
Special thanks to Radha Friedman for providing Fig. 4 of this article.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Countries that DGHP supported for training and/or outbreak response from 2006 to 2016
